canonical_explanation.text: The s-block elements comprise Group 1 (alkali metals: Li, Na, K, Rb, Cs, Fr) and Group 2 (alkaline earth metals: Be, Mg, Ca, Sr, Ba, Ra). Their general electronic configuration is [noble gas] ns¹ (Group 1) and [noble gas] ns² (Group 2). Alkali metals have the largest atomic radii in their respective periods and the lowest ionisation enthalpies, making them the most electropositive and reactive metals. Down the group, atomic radius increases, ionisation enthalpy decreases, and reactivity increases. They are soft metals with low melting and boiling points (decrease down the group due to weakening metallic bonding), silvery-white, and excellent conductors of heat and electricity. They impart characteristic flame colours: Li (crimson red), Na (golden yellow), K (violet), Rb (red-violet), Cs (blue). Alkali metals react vigorously with water: 2M + 2H₂O → 2MOH + H₂ (reactivity increases from Li to Cs). They burn in excess oxygen: Li forms Li₂O (oxide), Na forms Na₂O₂ (peroxide), K/Rb/Cs form MO₂ (superoxide). They react with hydrogen to form ionic hydrides (MH), with halogens to form halides (MX), and dissolve in liquid ammonia to form blue conducting solutions containing solvated electrons (M + (x+y)NH₃ → M⁺(NH₃)ₓ + e⁻(NH₃)ᵧ). Sodium hydroxide (NaOH, caustic soda) is manufactured by Castner-Kellner process (mercury cathode cell electrolysis of brine) or diaphragm cell or membrane cell. Sodium carbonate (Na₂CO₃, washing soda) is manufactured by the Solvay process: NaCl + NH₃ + CO₂ + H₂O → NaHCO₃ + NH₄Cl; 2NaHCO₃ →(heat) Na₂CO₃ + H₂O + CO₂. Na₂CO₃·10H₂O is washing soda (efflorescent). Sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO₃, baking soda) decomposes on heating: 2NaHCO₃ → Na₂CO₃ + H₂O + CO₂ (used in fire extinguishers and baking). KOH (caustic potash) is used in soft soap, KCl is used as fertiliser, KNO₃ (saltpetre) is used in gunpowder. Alkaline earth metals have smaller atomic radii and higher ionisation enthalpies than corresponding alkali metals. They are harder, denser, and have higher melting points. Flame colours: Ca (brick red), Sr (crimson), Ba (apple green); Be and Mg do not impart flame colour because their ionisation enthalpies are too high. Be shows anomalous behaviour due to very small size, high charge density, and absence of d-orbitals: it forms covalent compounds (BeCl₂ is linear and polymeric), does not react with water, its oxide and hydroxide are amphoteric, and it shows diagonal relationship with aluminium (both form covalent compounds, both have amphoteric oxides, both form carbides that give methane with water). Mg burns in air with a dazzling white flame: 2Mg + O₂ → 2MgO. Compounds of calcium: CaO (quicklime) is formed by calcination of limestone (CaCO₃ → CaO + CO₂). Ca(OH)₂ (slaked lime) is formed by adding water to CaO. CaCO₃ exists as calcite and aragonite. CaSO₄·½H₂O is plaster of Paris (sets by forming CaSO₄·2H₂O, gypsum). MgSO₄·7H₂O is Epsom salt. MgCO₃ is used as an antacid. Cement is a mixture of calcium silicates and aluminates obtained by heating limestone with clay.
rules: Alkali metals: [noble gas] ns¹; largest atomic radii, lowest IE, most electropositive in their period.
Reactivity with water increases down Group 1: Li (slow) to Cs (explosive).
Products with excess O₂: Li→Li₂O (normal oxide), Na→Na₂O₂ (peroxide), K/Rb/Cs→MO₂ (superoxide).
Flame colours: Li=crimson red, Na=golden yellow, K=violet, Ca=brick red, Sr=crimson, Ba=apple green.
Alkali metals dissolve in liquid NH₃ giving blue colour due to solvated electrons; concentrated solutions are bronze/copper-coloured and diamagnetic.
Solvay process for Na₂CO₃: NaCl + NH₃ + CO₂ + H₂O → NaHCO₃↓ + NH₄Cl; 2NaHCO₃ →(Δ) Na₂CO₃ + H₂O + CO₂.
NaOH (caustic soda): manufactured by electrolysis of brine (Castner-Kellner/membrane cell).
Alkaline earth metals: [noble gas] ns²; smaller, harder, higher IE than corresponding alkali metals.
Be is anomalous: small size, no d-orbitals, forms covalent compounds, amphoteric oxide/hydroxide, diagonal relationship with Al.
CaO + H₂O → Ca(OH)₂ (exothermic); CaCO₃ →(900°C) CaO + CO₂ (calcination).
Plaster of Paris: CaSO₄·½H₂O; sets by absorbing water to form gypsum CaSO₄·2H₂O.
Mg burns in air with dazzling white flame forming MgO; also burns in N₂ forming Mg₃N₂.

questions.question_text: The general electronic configuration of alkali metals (Group 1) is:
questions.explanation_correct: Alkali metals (Li, Na, K, Rb, Cs, Fr) belong to Group 1 and have the general electronic configuration [noble gas] ns¹, where n is the principal quantum number of the outermost shell. They have one electron in their valence s-orbital, which they readily lose to form M⁺ ions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: [noble gas] ns² is the configuration of alkaline earth metals (Group 2). [noble gas] ns² np¹ is the configuration of Group 13 elements (boron family). [noble gas] (n−1)d¹ ns² is the configuration of Group 3 transition metals. Alkali metals have exactly one valence electron in the ns orbital.

questions.question_text: Which of the following alkali metals has the lowest ionisation enthalpy?
questions.explanation_correct: Caesium has the lowest ionisation enthalpy among alkali metals (375.7 kJ/mol). Down Group 1, atomic size increases due to addition of new electron shells, and the outermost electron is farther from the nucleus with greater shielding. This makes it progressively easier to remove the valence electron: Li (520) > Na (496) > K (419) > Rb (403) > Cs (376) kJ/mol.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lithium has the highest ionisation enthalpy in the group due to its smallest size. Ionisation enthalpy decreases steadily down the group as atomic radius increases and the valence electron becomes easier to remove. Caesium, being the largest, has the lowest IE.

questions.question_text: The flame colour produced by sodium compounds is:
questions.explanation_correct: Sodium and its compounds impart a persistent golden yellow colour to the flame. When heated, the outer electron of Na is excited from the 3s to the 3p level. When it returns to the ground state, it emits radiation at 589 nm (sodium D-lines), which falls in the yellow region of the visible spectrum.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Crimson red is the flame colour of lithium. Violet is the flame colour of potassium (often masked by sodium's yellow and observed through cobalt blue glass). Apple green is the flame colour of barium. Golden yellow is characteristic and unique to sodium.

questions.question_text: Alkali metals are stored under kerosene oil because they:

options.text: Are highly volatile and sublimate at room temperature
Are highly reactive and tarnish rapidly in air by reacting with O₂ and moisture
Dissolve in water to form acidic solutions
React with nitrogen in air to form explosive nitrides

questions.explanation_correct: Alkali metals are extremely reactive and readily react with oxygen and moisture in air. Sodium tarnishes within seconds in air, forming a layer of oxide (Na₂O) and then hydroxide (NaOH, which absorbs moisture). To prevent this, they are stored under kerosene oil (an inert hydrocarbon liquid) that keeps them isolated from air and moisture. Lithium, being lighter than kerosene, is stored in paraffin wax.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Alkali metals are not volatile at room temperature (they are solid metals). They form strongly basic (not acidic) solutions with water. While Li forms Li₃N with nitrogen, this is not explosive and is not the primary reason for storage under kerosene. The main reason is their vigorous reaction with atmospheric O₂ and H₂O.

questions.question_text: When alkali metals dissolve in liquid ammonia, the resulting solution is blue in colour due to:

options.text: Dissolution of the metal to form a colloidal suspension

questions.explanation_correct: When alkali metals dissolve in liquid ammonia, they ionise: M + (x+y)NH₃ → M⁺(NH₃)ₓ + e⁻(NH₃)ᵧ. The solvated electrons (ammoniated electrons) are responsible for the intense blue colour of dilute solutions. These solvated electrons also make the solution paramagnetic and an excellent reducing agent. At higher concentrations, the solution becomes bronze/copper-coloured and diamagnetic due to clustering of solvated electrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Metal amides (MNH₂) form slowly as a side reaction but do not cause the blue colour. There is no metal-ammonia complex ion formation. The metal dissolves as ions, not colloidal particles. The blue colour is specifically due to the absorption of light in the visible region by solvated (ammoniated) electrons.

questions.question_text: The correct order of atomic radii of alkali metals is:
questions.explanation_correct: Atomic radius increases down Group 1 as new electron shells are added: Li (152 pm) < Na (186 pm) < K (227 pm) < Rb (248 pm) < Cs (265 pm). Each successive element has one additional principal energy level, increasing the distance of the outermost electron from the nucleus despite the increase in nuclear charge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Atomic radius increases (not decreases) going down the group. The order Li > Na > K > Rb > Cs would be correct for ionisation enthalpy or electronegativity (which decrease down the group), not for atomic radius. The correct trend is Cs (largest) > Rb > K > Na > Li (smallest).

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Lithium has the most negative standard electrode potential (E° = −3.04 V) among alkali metals despite having the highest ionisation enthalpy.
Reason: Lithium has a very high hydration enthalpy due to its small ionic size.

options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason correctly explains the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but Reason does NOT correctly explain the Assertion
Assertion is true but Reason is false

questions.explanation_correct: Both are true and the Reason correctly explains the Assertion. The standard electrode potential depends on sublimation energy + ionisation energy + hydration energy. Although Li has the highest IE among alkali metals (520 kJ/mol), its very small ionic radius (76 pm) leads to an exceptionally high hydration enthalpy (−520 kJ/mol), which more than compensates for the high IE. The overall result is the most negative E° value, making Li the strongest reducing agent in aqueous solution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Assertion is factually true (Li has E° = −3.04 V, most negative). The Reason is also true (Li⁺ has very high hydration enthalpy due to small size). And the Reason correctly explains why Li has the most negative E° despite its high IE — the enormous energy released during hydration compensates.

questions.question_text: When sodium burns in excess oxygen, the main product formed is:
questions.explanation_correct: When sodium burns in excess oxygen, it predominantly forms sodium peroxide (Na₂O₂): 2Na + O₂ → Na₂O₂. This is because Na⁺ has the right size to stabilise the peroxide ion O₂²⁻ in the crystal lattice. In limited oxygen, Na forms Na₂O (normal oxide). Heavier alkali metals (K, Rb, Cs) form superoxides (MO₂) with excess O₂.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Na₂O forms only with limited oxygen supply. NaO₂ (superoxide) is formed by heavier alkali metals (K, Rb, Cs), not sodium. Na₂O₃ is not a known stable compound. The size of Na⁺ stabilises the peroxide ion O₂²⁻, making Na₂O₂ the primary product with excess O₂.

questions.question_text: The reaction of potassium with water is:

options.text: 2K + 2H₂O → 2KOH + H₂↑ (vigorous, may ignite the hydrogen produced)
K + H₂O → KOH + ½O₂ (slow, no gas evolution)
K + H₂O → KH + ½O₂ (formation of potassium hydride)

questions.explanation_correct: Potassium reacts vigorously with water: 2K + 2H₂O → 2KOH + H₂↑. The reaction is so exothermic that the hydrogen gas produced catches fire and burns with a lilac (violet) flame. Potassium is more reactive than sodium with water because of its lower ionisation enthalpy and larger atomic size.
questions.explanation_incorrect: K is monovalent and forms KOH, not K(OH)₂. The products are KOH and H₂ (hydrogen gas), not O₂ or KH. The reaction is vigorous, not slow — potassium can ignite spontaneously on contact with water due to the highly exothermic nature of the reaction.

questions.question_text: Which of the following alkali metals forms only the normal oxide (M₂O) when burned in excess oxygen?
questions.explanation_correct: Lithium, when burned in excess oxygen, forms only the normal oxide Li₂O: 4Li + O₂ → 2Li₂O. Due to its small size, Li⁺ can stabilise only the small O²⁻ ion, not the larger O₂²⁻ (peroxide) or O₂⁻ (superoxide) ions. This is an example of lithium's anomalous behaviour within Group 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sodium forms peroxide (Na₂O₂) with excess O₂. Potassium and caesium form superoxides (KO₂, CsO₂) with excess O₂. Only lithium, due to its very small cation size, exclusively forms the normal oxide Li₂O regardless of oxygen supply.

questions.question_text: Alkali metals form ionic hydrides when they react with hydrogen. The thermal stability of these hydrides follows the order:

options.text: All have the same thermal stability

questions.explanation_correct: The thermal stability of alkali metal hydrides decreases down the group: LiH > NaH > KH > RbH > CsH. As the metal cation size increases, the lattice energy of the hydride decreases (larger cation-anion distance weakens ionic bonding), making the compound easier to decompose thermally. LiH has the smallest cation and highest lattice energy, hence the greatest stability.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Thermal stability does not increase down the group. Larger alkali metal cations form weaker ionic bonds with H⁻, resulting in lower lattice energy and easier decomposition. LiH is the most thermally stable (decomposes above 900°C), while CsH is the least stable.

questions.question_text: Among alkali metals, lithium is the only one that directly combines with nitrogen to form a nitride. The product and the reaction are:
questions.explanation_correct: Lithium is the only alkali metal that directly reacts with nitrogen at room temperature to form lithium nitride: 6Li + N₂ → 2Li₃N. This is because Li⁺ is very small and has high charge density, which allows it to polarise the N³⁻ ion effectively and form a stable ionic compound. This behaviour is an example of lithium's anomalous character and its diagonal relationship with magnesium (which also forms Mg₃N₂).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct formula of lithium nitride is Li₃N (each Li loses 1 electron, and nitrogen gains 3). LiN, Li₂N₃, and LiN₃ do not represent the correct stoichiometry of lithium nitride. The balanced equation requires 6 Li atoms per N₂ molecule.

questions.question_text: The correct order of reactivity of alkali metals with water is:
questions.explanation_correct: Reactivity of alkali metals with water increases down the group: Li < Na < K < Rb < Cs. This is because ionisation enthalpy decreases and atomic size increases going down the group, making it easier for heavier metals to lose their valence electron. Li reacts slowly with cold water, Na reacts vigorously, K reacts violently with fire, and Cs reacts explosively on contact.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reactivity increases (not decreases) down Group 1. Li is the least reactive with water despite having the most negative E° value (the kinetics are slower because of higher IE). Cs is the most reactive, reacting explosively with water.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about alkali metal halides is INCORRECT?

options.text: All alkali metal halides (except LiF) are soluble in water
LiF is insoluble due to very high lattice energy
LiI is covalent in nature due to polarisation of the large I⁻ by small Li⁺
All alkali metal halides have body-centred cubic (BCC) crystal structure

questions.explanation_correct: The statement that all alkali metal halides have BCC structure is incorrect. Most alkali metal halides crystallise in the rock salt (NaCl-type, face-centred cubic) structure, not BCC. CsCl, CsBr, and CsI have the CsCl-type structure (where each ion is surrounded by 8 counterions, coordination number 8). The rest adopt the NaCl-type structure with coordination number 6.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is essentially correct (LiF has limited solubility). Option B is correct — LiF's very high lattice energy (due to small sizes of both Li⁺ and F⁻) exceeds its hydration energy, making it sparingly soluble. Option C is correct — Fajans' rules predict high covalent character when small, highly charged Li⁺ polarises the large, polarisable I⁻ ion.

questions.question_text:
Consider the products formed when alkali metals burn in excess oxygen:
Li → Product X; Na → Product Y; K → Product Z.
The correct identification is:

options.text: X = Li₂O₂, Y = Na₂O, Z = KO₂
X = Li₂O, Y = Na₂O₂, Z = KO₂
X = LiO₂, Y = Na₂O₂, Z = K₂O
X = Li₂O, Y = NaO₂, Z = K₂O₂

questions.explanation_correct: With excess O₂: Li forms the normal oxide Li₂O (X), Na forms the peroxide Na₂O₂ (Y), and K forms the superoxide KO₂ (Z). The product type depends on cation size: small Li⁺ stabilises only O²⁻; medium Na⁺ stabilises O₂²⁻; large K⁺, Rb⁺, Cs⁺ stabilise the even larger O₂⁻ (superoxide) ion through favourable lattice energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Li does not form peroxide or superoxide (its cation is too small). Na does not form superoxide (Na⁺ is not large enough). K does not form normal oxide or peroxide with excess O₂. The trend oxide → peroxide → superoxide correlates with increasing cation size down the group.

questions.question_text: Sodium carbonate (Na₂CO₃) is industrially manufactured by the:

options.text: Leblanc process only (no modern process exists)

questions.explanation_correct: Na₂CO₃ (washing soda) is manufactured by the Solvay process (also called the ammonia-soda process). In this process, CO₂ is passed through an ammoniacal brine solution: NaCl + NH₃ + CO₂ + H₂O → NaHCO₃↓ + NH₄Cl. The sparingly soluble NaHCO₃ precipitates, is filtered, and heated to give Na₂CO₃: 2NaHCO₃ → Na₂CO₃ + H₂O + CO₂. NH₃ is recovered from NH₄Cl using Ca(OH)₂.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Haber process produces ammonia. The Contact process produces sulphuric acid. The Leblanc process was an older method for Na₂CO₃ that has been completely replaced by the Solvay process, which is more economical and efficient.

questions.question_text: Baking soda (NaHCO₃) is used in fire extinguishers because when heated it:

options.text: Produces oxygen that smothers the flame
Decomposes to release CO₂ gas which extinguishes fire
Melts and coats the burning material with a protective layer

questions.explanation_correct: NaHCO₃ (baking soda) decomposes on heating: 2NaHCO₃ → Na₂CO₃ + H₂O + CO₂↑. The CO₂ released is a non-combustible gas that is denser than air. It blankets the fire, cutting off the oxygen supply and extinguishing it. In soda-acid fire extinguishers, NaHCO₃ reacts with dilute H₂SO₄ to produce CO₂ instantly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: NaHCO₃ does not produce O₂ (which would fuel the fire). It does not melt to form a coating. It does decompose (rather than remaining intact). The key product is CO₂, which is heavier than air and non-combustible, smothering the fire by displacing oxygen.

questions.question_text: NaOH (caustic soda) is manufactured by the electrolysis of brine. In the Castner-Kellner cell, the cathode is made of:
questions.explanation_correct: In the Castner-Kellner cell (mercury cathode cell), mercury acts as the cathode. When brine (NaCl solution) is electrolysed, Na⁺ is reduced at the mercury cathode to form sodium amalgam (Na-Hg). The amalgam then reacts with water in a separate compartment to produce NaOH and H₂: 2Na-Hg + 2H₂O → 2NaOH + H₂ + 2Hg. Chlorine is liberated at the graphite anode.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Iron is the cathode in the diaphragm cell (Nelson cell), not the Castner-Kellner cell. Graphite is the anode material. The distinguishing feature of the Castner-Kellner cell is the use of a flowing mercury cathode, which selectively deposits sodium as amalgam, producing high-purity NaOH.

questions.question_text: Washing soda (Na₂CO₃·10H₂O) when exposed to dry air undergoes:

options.text: Efflorescence — loses water of crystallisation to form Na₂CO₃·H₂O
No change — it is perfectly stable in air

questions.explanation_correct: Na₂CO₃·10H₂O (washing soda) is an efflorescent substance. When exposed to dry air, it spontaneously loses its water of crystallisation and forms the monohydrate Na₂CO₃·H₂O, becoming a white powder on the surface. Efflorescence occurs when the vapour pressure of the hydrate exceeds the partial pressure of water vapour in the air.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Deliquescence (absorbing moisture to dissolve) is shown by NaOH, CaCl₂, etc., not washing soda. Washing soda does the opposite — it loses water (efflorescence). It is definitely not stable in dry air and undergoes visible change as it loses water of crystallisation.

questions.question_text: In the Solvay process, the reaction NaCl + NH₃ + CO₂ + H₂O → NaHCO₃ + NH₄Cl succeeds because:

options.text: NaCl is insoluble in ammoniacal solution
NaHCO₃ is the least soluble among the four possible products and precipitates out
NH₄Cl decomposes at room temperature releasing NH₃
CO₂ is highly soluble in brine, driving the reaction to completion

questions.explanation_correct: The Solvay process works because NaHCO₃ is the least soluble of the four possible ionic combinations (NaHCO₃, NaCl, NH₄HCO₃, NH₄Cl) in the cold ammoniacal brine solution. Its low solubility causes it to precipitate, driving the equilibrium forward according to Le Chatelier's principle. The precipitated NaHCO₃ is filtered and heated to give Na₂CO₃.
questions.explanation_incorrect: NaCl is soluble in ammoniacal solution (it's the starting material dissolved in the solution). NH₄Cl does not decompose at room temperature. CO₂ has limited solubility in brine; NH₃ is added precisely to increase CO₂ absorption by forming NH₄HCO₃ intermediate. The key principle is the low solubility of NaHCO₃.

questions.question_text: KNO₃ (potassium nitrate, saltpetre) is a component of gunpowder. The other two components are:
questions.explanation_correct: Gunpowder (black powder) is a mixture of KNO₃ (75%), charcoal/carbon (15%), and sulphur (10%). KNO₃ acts as the oxidiser, providing oxygen for the combustion of charcoal and sulphur. The reaction produces large volumes of gases (CO₂, N₂, SO₂) rapidly, creating the explosive effect.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gunpowder does not contain iron filings, aluminium, phosphorus, magnesium, sodium carbonate, or lead oxide. The traditional composition is specifically KNO₃ + charcoal + sulphur. Other metal powders may be used in different types of pyrotechnics but not in classical gunpowder.

questions.question_text: The Solvay process cannot be used to manufacture K₂CO₃ because:

options.text: KHCO₃ is too soluble in the reaction mixture and does not precipitate out
K does not react with CO₂
NH₃ reacts with K⁺ ions forming an insoluble complex

questions.explanation_correct: The Solvay process relies on the low solubility of NaHCO₃, which precipitates from the ammoniacal brine. KHCO₃ is much more soluble than NaHCO₃ in the reaction mixture, so it does not precipitate out when the analogous reaction is attempted with KCl. Without precipitation of the bicarbonate, the process fails to produce K₂CO₃. Instead, K₂CO₃ is made by the Engel-Precht process or by reacting KOH with CO₂.
questions.explanation_incorrect: KCl is abundantly available (e.g., sylvite mineral). K⁺ does not form an insoluble complex with NH₃. Potassium compounds can react with CO₂. The sole reason the Solvay process fails for K₂CO₃ is the high solubility of KHCO₃, which prevents its precipitation.

questions.question_text: When Na₂O₂ (sodium peroxide) is treated with water, the products formed are:
questions.explanation_correct: Sodium peroxide reacts with water: 2Na₂O₂ + 2H₂O → 4NaOH + O₂↑. The peroxide ion O₂²⁻ undergoes disproportionation: it is simultaneously oxidised (to O₂, oxidation state 0) and reduced (to OH⁻, oxidation state −2). This reaction makes Na₂O₂ useful in submarines and spacecraft as it generates O₂ and removes CO₂ from expired air.
questions.explanation_incorrect: H₂ is produced when alkali metals or their normal oxides (Na₂O) react with water, not peroxides. Na₂O₂ + H₂O initially forms NaOH and H₂O₂, but H₂O₂ is unstable and quickly decomposes to H₂O + ½O₂. The net products are NaOH and O₂.

questions.question_text: The general electronic configuration of alkaline earth metals (Group 2) is:
questions.explanation_correct: Alkaline earth metals (Be, Mg, Ca, Sr, Ba, Ra) have the general electronic configuration [noble gas] ns², with two electrons in the outermost s-orbital. They lose both valence electrons to form M²⁺ divalent cations. Their ionisation enthalpies are higher than corresponding alkali metals because of the extra nuclear charge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: [noble gas] ns¹ is for alkali metals (Group 1). [noble gas] ns² np¹ is for Group 13. [noble gas] (n−1)d² ns² is for Group 4 transition metals. Alkaline earth metals specifically have two s-electrons in their valence shell.

questions.question_text: Which pair of alkaline earth metals does NOT impart any colour to the flame?
questions.explanation_correct: Beryllium and magnesium do not impart colour to the flame because their atoms are very small and their ionisation enthalpies are too high. The energy of the flame is insufficient to excite their electrons to higher energy levels. Ca (brick red), Sr (crimson), and Ba (apple green) all show characteristic flame colours because their electrons can be excited by flame energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ca gives brick-red, Sr gives crimson, and Ba gives apple green flame colours. Only Be and Mg, due to their small sizes and high ionisation enthalpies, do not show flame colouration. The flame test is applicable only to heavier alkaline earth metals.

questions.question_text: Compared to alkali metals, alkaline earth metals are:

options.text: Harder, with higher melting points and smaller atomic radii

questions.explanation_correct: Alkaline earth metals are harder, denser, and have higher melting and boiling points than the corresponding alkali metals. This is because they have two valence electrons contributing to metallic bonding (stronger bonding), smaller atomic radii (higher nuclear charge without additional shell), and higher charge density. They are less electropositive and less reactive than alkali metals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Alkaline earth metals are harder (not softer) due to stronger metallic bonding from two valence electrons. They are less electropositive (not more) because of higher ionisation enthalpies. Their electrical conductivity is generally comparable to or less than alkali metals, not specifically better.

questions.question_text: Magnesium burns in air with a dazzling white flame. The products formed are:
questions.explanation_correct: When magnesium burns in air, it reacts with both oxygen and nitrogen present in air: 2Mg + O₂ → 2MgO (white, major product) and 3Mg + N₂ → Mg₃N₂ (yellowish, minor product). MgO is the predominant product, but the formation of Mg₃N₂ is a notable reaction since most metals do not react with atmospheric nitrogen at these temperatures.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mg does not form MgO₂ (peroxide) — it forms only the normal oxide MgO. MgCO₃ is not formed by burning (it would require CO₂ reaction under pressure). The correct answer includes both MgO (from reaction with O₂) and Mg₃N₂ (from reaction with N₂ in air).

questions.question_text: The solubility of alkaline earth metal hydroxides in water follows the order:
questions.explanation_correct: The solubility of alkaline earth metal hydroxides increases down the group: Be(OH)₂ < Mg(OH)₂ < Ca(OH)₂ < Sr(OH)₂ < Ba(OH)₂. As the cation size increases, the lattice enthalpy decreases more rapidly than the hydration enthalpy, making dissolution more favourable. Be(OH)₂ and Mg(OH)₂ are sparingly soluble, while Ba(OH)₂ is quite soluble.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Solubility increases (not decreases) down the group for hydroxides. This is because the decrease in lattice energy dominates over the decrease in hydration energy for large OH⁻ anion. Ba(OH)₂ (baryta water) is significantly soluble, while Mg(OH)₂ (milk of magnesia) is sparingly soluble.

questions.question_text: The solubility of alkaline earth metal sulphates in water follows the order:

options.text: All sulphates have the same solubility

questions.explanation_correct: The solubility of alkaline earth metal sulphates decreases down the group: BeSO₄ > MgSO₄ > CaSO₄ > SrSO₄ > BaSO₄. For sulphates, the hydration enthalpy decreases more rapidly than the lattice enthalpy as cation size increases (because SO₄²⁻ is a large anion, so lattice energy changes are relatively small). BeSO₄ and MgSO₄ are readily soluble, CaSO₄ is sparingly soluble, and BaSO₄ is virtually insoluble.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sulphate solubility decreases (opposite to hydroxide solubility) down the group. BaSO₄ is one of the most insoluble salts known (Ksp ≈ 1.1 × 10⁻¹⁰), while MgSO₄ (Epsom salt) and BeSO₄ are very soluble. This opposite trend to hydroxides is a classic NCERT concept.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Alkaline earth metals have higher ionisation enthalpies than the corresponding alkali metals in the same period.
Reason: Alkaline earth metals have smaller atomic size and one extra nuclear charge compared to the corresponding alkali metals.

options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason is the correct explanation
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but Reason is NOT the correct explanation
Assertion is true but Reason is false

questions.explanation_correct: Both are true and the Reason correctly explains the Assertion. Alkaline earth metals (Group 2) have higher nuclear charge (+1 more proton) than the corresponding alkali metals (Group 1) in the same period, without an additional electron shell. This results in greater effective nuclear charge, smaller atomic radius, and hence higher ionisation enthalpy. For example, Na (496 kJ/mol) < Mg (737 kJ/mol); K (419) < Ca (590).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Assertion is factually correct — Group 2 elements always have higher IE₁ than the adjacent Group 1 element in the same period. The Reason accurately explains this by citing smaller size and higher nuclear charge, which are the fundamental causes.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly describes the trend in thermal stability of alkaline earth metal carbonates?

options.text: All carbonates have equal thermal stability

questions.explanation_correct: The thermal stability of alkaline earth metal carbonates increases down the group: BeCO₃ < MgCO₃ < CaCO₃ < SrCO₃ < BaCO₃. Smaller cations (Be²⁺, Mg²⁺) have high polarising power and can distort the electron cloud of the large CO₃²⁻ ion, weakening the C–O bond and facilitating decomposition at lower temperatures. Larger cations (Ba²⁺) have lower polarising power and their carbonates require higher temperatures to decompose.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Thermal stability increases (not decreases) down the group. BeCO₃ is so unstable that it exists only in a CO₂ atmosphere. BaCO₃ requires temperatures above 1300°C for decomposition. The polarising power of the cation (which decreases down the group) determines the ease of decomposition.

questions.question_text: Quicklime (CaO) is obtained by heating:

options.text: CaSO₄ in the presence of carbon

questions.explanation_correct: Quicklime (CaO) is manufactured by calcination of limestone (CaCO₃) at about 1070 K in a rotary kiln: CaCO₃ →(Δ) CaO + CO₂↑. This process is called calcination — thermal decomposition of a carbonate to form the oxide and CO₂. CaO is a white, amorphous solid that reacts vigorously with water to form Ca(OH)₂ (slaked lime).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Heating Ca(OH)₂ would first dehydrate it, but the standard industrial source of CaO is limestone (CaCO₃). CaSO₄ decomposition requires very high temperatures and different products. CaCl₂ does not give CaO on heating in air. Calcination of CaCO₃ is the standard industrial method.

questions.question_text: Plaster of Paris has the chemical formula:
questions.explanation_correct: Plaster of Paris is calcium sulphate hemihydrate: CaSO₄·½H₂O (or (CaSO₄)₂·H₂O). It is prepared by heating gypsum (CaSO₄·2H₂O) at 393 K: 2(CaSO₄·2H₂O) →(393 K) (CaSO₄)₂·H₂O + 3H₂O. When mixed with water, it sets by forming the dihydrate (gypsum) again, expanding slightly and forming a hard mass.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CaSO₄·2H₂O is gypsum (the starting material). Anhydrous CaSO₄ (dead burnt plaster) does not set with water. CaCO₃·H₂O is not a known compound. Plaster of Paris is specifically the hemihydrate with the formula CaSO₄·½H₂O.

questions.question_text: Epsom salt has the chemical formula:
questions.explanation_correct: Epsom salt is magnesium sulphate heptahydrate (MgSO₄·7H₂O). It is named after the town of Epsom in Surrey, England, where it was first discovered in mineral springs. It is used as a purgative in medicine, in dyeing and tanning industries, and as a source of magnesium in agriculture.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Na₂SO₄·10H₂O is Glauber's salt. CaSO₄·2H₂O is gypsum. FeSO₄·7H₂O is green vitriol (ferrous sulphate). Epsom salt is specifically MgSO₄·7H₂O.

questions.question_text: When Plaster of Paris (CaSO₄·½H₂O) is mixed with water, it sets to form a hard mass. The chemical reaction involved is:
questions.explanation_correct: When Plaster of Paris is mixed with water, it absorbs water and re-forms gypsum: CaSO₄·½H₂O + 1½H₂O → CaSO₄·2H₂O. The hemihydrate absorbs 1½ molecules of water per formula unit to form the dihydrate (gypsum). During this process, the crystals interlock, causing the mixture to set into a hard, rigid mass with slight expansion — useful for making casts, moulds, and surgical bandages.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CaSO₄·H₂O (monohydrate) is not the correct product — the setting product is the dihydrate CaSO₄·2H₂O (gypsum). Plaster of Paris does not lose water (option C describes dead-burning). It does not decompose into Ca(OH)₂ and H₂SO₄. The correct reaction adds 1½H₂O to form gypsum.

questions.question_text: Beryllium shows a diagonal relationship with aluminium. Which of the following properties is common to both Be and Al?

options.text: Both are highly electropositive and form ionic compounds predominantly
Both form amphoteric oxides and hydroxides
Both form stable superoxides with excess oxygen
Both dissolve in liquid ammonia to give blue solutions

questions.explanation_correct: Both beryllium and aluminium form amphoteric oxides and hydroxides. BeO dissolves in both acid (BeO + 2HCl → BeCl₂ + H₂O) and alkali (BeO + 2NaOH → Na₂BeO₂ + H₂O). Similarly, Al₂O₃ dissolves in acid and alkali. Other common properties include: both form covalent compounds (BeCl₂ and AlCl₃), both form carbides that give methane with water (Be₂C and Al₄C₃), and both are rendered passive by conc. HNO₃.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both Be and Al tend to form covalent (not ionic) compounds due to high charge density. Neither forms stable superoxides. Be does not dissolve in liquid ammonia to give blue solutions (that is characteristic of alkali metals). The key shared property is the amphoteric nature of their oxides and hydroxides.

questions.question_text: Portland cement is manufactured by heating a mixture of:

options.text: Limestone (CaCO₃) and clay (aluminosilicates) at about 1770 K in a rotary kiln

questions.explanation_correct: Portland cement is manufactured by heating a mixture of limestone (CaCO₃, providing CaO) and clay (which contains aluminosilicates — SiO₂ and Al₂O₃) at about 1770 K in a rotary kiln. The product (called clinite) is ground with about 2-3% gypsum (CaSO₄·2H₂O) to form cement. The major components are tricalcium silicate (3CaO·SiO₂), dicalcium silicate (2CaO·SiO₂), and tricalcium aluminate (3CaO·Al₂O₃).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cement requires both lime (from CaCO₃) and alumina/silica (from clay), not just CaCO₃ and SiO₂. MgCO₃ with Al₂O₃ at 500 K would not form cement. CaSO₄ with charcoal is not a cement-making recipe. The kiln temperature must be around 1770 K for the proper calcium silicate and aluminate phases to form.

questions.question_text: The reason BeCl₂ is covalent rather than ionic (unlike other Group 2 chlorides) is:

options.text: Be²⁺ has very high polarising power due to small size and high charge, strongly distorting Cl⁻ electron cloud (Fajans' rules)
Beryllium has d-orbitals available for back bonding
BeCl₂ exists as a gas at room temperature

questions.explanation_correct: According to Fajans' rules, a compound becomes more covalent when the cation is small with high charge (high charge density = high polarising power) and the anion is large and easily polarisable. Be²⁺ is the smallest divalent cation (ionic radius ~31 pm) with very high charge density. It strongly polarises the electron cloud of Cl⁻, leading to significant covalent character. BeCl₂ is a covalent solid with a polymeric chain structure (bridged chlorines).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chlorine has relatively high electronegativity (3.0). Beryllium does NOT have d-orbitals in its valence shell (it has only 1s² 2s² — no 2d). BeCl₂ is a solid at room temperature, not a gas. The covalent nature is explained by the exceptionally high polarising power of Be²⁺ (Fajans' rules).

questions.question_text:
Consider the following properties of beryllium:
(i) BeCl₂ is a covalent compound with polymeric structure
(ii) Be(OH)₂ is amphoteric
(iii) Be does not react with water even at high temperatures
(iv) Be₂C on hydrolysis gives acetylene (C₂H₂)
Which of the above statements is/are INCORRECT?
questions.explanation_correct: Statement (iv) is incorrect. Be₂C on hydrolysis gives methane (CH₄), not acetylene: Be₂C + 4H₂O → 2Be(OH)₂ + CH₄. The carbide that gives acetylene is CaC₂ (calcium carbide): CaC₂ + 2H₂O → Ca(OH)₂ + C₂H₂. Be₂C is a methanide (contains C⁴⁻). Statements (i), (ii), and (iii) are all correct properties of beryllium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Statements (i), (ii), and (iii) are all correct. BeCl₂ is indeed covalent and polymeric. Be(OH)₂ is amphoteric (dissolves in both acids and bases). Beryllium is kinetically inert towards water due to formation of a protective oxide layer. Only (iv) is wrong — Be₂C gives CH₄, not C₂H₂.

questions.question_text: The setting of Plaster of Paris is accompanied by:

options.text: Contraction in volume and absorption of heat
Expansion in volume and evolution of heat
No change in volume and no heat effect
Contraction in volume and evolution of heat

questions.explanation_correct: The setting of Plaster of Paris is an exothermic process (heat is evolved) accompanied by slight expansion in volume (about 1%). The reaction CaSO₄·½H₂O + 1½H₂O → CaSO₄·2H₂O releases energy as new hydration bonds form. The slight expansion ensures that the plaster fills moulds completely and reproduces fine details, making it ideal for casts and moulds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The setting process involves hydration (exothermic, not endothermic) and slight expansion (not contraction). The expansion is important practically — if it contracted, plaster casts would not fit properly and moulds would lose detail. The combination of expansion and heat evolution is characteristic of plaster setting.

questions.question_text: Why does potassium flame appear violet, yet it is observed through a cobalt blue glass in flame tests?

options.text: Cobalt blue glass amplifies the violet colour of potassium
Cobalt blue glass absorbs the intense yellow light of sodium (which is often present as impurity), allowing the weaker violet colour of potassium to be seen
Cobalt blue glass converts sodium's yellow flame to violet
Potassium does not produce any flame colour without the blue glass

questions.explanation_correct: Sodium is a common impurity in most potassium compounds. Sodium's intense golden yellow flame (589 nm) overpowers potassium's violet flame (766 nm). Cobalt blue glass selectively absorbs yellow light while transmitting blue-violet light, allowing the observer to see potassium's characteristic violet colour without interference from sodium's yellow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cobalt blue glass does not amplify or convert any colour. Potassium does produce a violet flame on its own, but it is masked by sodium's much more intense yellow emission. The glass acts as a filter, absorbing yellow and transmitting violet light.

questions.question_text: Sodium dissolves in liquid ammonia. Over time, in the presence of an iron catalyst, the blue solution slowly produces:
questions.explanation_correct: When alkali metals dissolve in liquid ammonia, they initially form a blue solution of solvated electrons. Over time, especially in the presence of a catalyst like iron, the solvated electrons react with ammonia: M⁺ + e⁻ + NH₃ → MNH₂ + ½H₂. For sodium: Na + NH₃ → NaNH₂ + ½H₂. Sodamide (NaNH₂) is the amide product, and hydrogen gas is evolved. This is the basis for preparing metal amides.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Na₃N (sodium nitride) does not form from liquid ammonia reactions. NaOH requires water. Na₂O and N₂ are not products of this reaction. The reaction involves deprotonation of NH₃ by the solvated electron, yielding the amide (NH₂⁻) and H₂ gas.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a use of sodium hydroxide (NaOH)?

options.text: Petroleum refining and purification of bauxite (Bayer's process)

questions.explanation_correct: NaOH is NOT used as a fertiliser. Fertilisers are typically salts of nitrogen (NH₄NO₃, urea), phosphorus (superphosphate), or potassium (KCl, K₂SO₄). NaOH is a strong corrosive base used in soap manufacture (saponification), rayon production, paper manufacturing, petroleum refining, and Bayer's process for extracting alumina from bauxite ore.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All of options A, B, and C are correct uses of NaOH. Saponification (fat + NaOH → soap + glycerol) is a major application. NaOH is essential in the viscose process for making rayon. In the Bayer process, NaOH dissolves Al₂O₃ from bauxite as NaAlO₂. Only its use as a fertiliser is incorrect.

questions.question_text: The flame colour imparted by barium compounds is:
questions.explanation_correct: Barium compounds impart an apple green (or grassy green) colour to the flame. When heated, the outer electrons of barium are excited and upon returning to the ground state, they emit radiation in the green region of the visible spectrum. This is a distinguishing test for barium in qualitative analysis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Brick red is the flame colour of calcium. Crimson is the flame colour of strontium (and lithium gives crimson red). Golden yellow is sodium's flame colour. Apple green is uniquely characteristic of barium.

questions.question_text: The reaction of quicklime (CaO) with water is:

options.text: CaO + H₂O → Ca(OH)₂ (highly exothermic, produces slaked lime)

questions.explanation_correct: CaO (quicklime) reacts vigorously with water in a highly exothermic reaction: CaO + H₂O → Ca(OH)₂ (slaked lime). So much heat is produced that the water can boil (this process is called slaking). Ca(OH)₂ (slaked lime) is a white powder sparingly soluble in water; its saturated solution is called lime water, used to test for CO₂.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CaO does not form CaH₂ (calcium hydride requires direct reaction of Ca with H₂). CaCO₃ forms only when CO₂ is present. The reaction is highly exothermic (not endothermic or without heat change) and produces Ca(OH)₂, which is the correct product.

questions.question_text: When CO₂ is passed through lime water [Ca(OH)₂ solution], it first turns milky due to formation of CaCO₃. On passing excess CO₂, the solution becomes clear again because:

options.text: CaCO₃ decomposes back to CaO and CO₂
CaCO₃ dissolves in excess CO₂ to form soluble Ca(HCO₃)₂
CO₂ removes the calcium as CaCl₂
CaCO₃ converts to CaO₂ which is soluble

questions.explanation_correct: When limited CO₂ is passed: Ca(OH)₂ + CO₂ → CaCO₃↓ + H₂O (milky due to insoluble CaCO₃). When excess CO₂ is passed: CaCO₃ + CO₂ + H₂O → Ca(HCO₃)₂ (soluble). The insoluble calcium carbonate converts to soluble calcium bicarbonate, and the solution turns clear again. On heating this clear solution, CaCO₃ precipitates again (reversible).
questions.explanation_incorrect: CaCO₃ does not decompose at room temperature — it requires very high temperatures (>1070 K). CO₂ does not form CaCl₂ (no chlorine source). CaO₂ is not formed from CaCO₃ + CO₂. The correct explanation is the formation of the soluble bicarbonate Ca(HCO₃)₂.

questions.question_text: Which statement about the anomalous behaviour of beryllium is INCORRECT?

options.text: Be does not form any compounds with oxygen
Be has no vacant d-orbitals in its valence shell, limiting its coordination number to 4
BeCl₂ is a covalent compound while CaCl₂ is ionic
Be shows diagonal relationship with aluminium

questions.explanation_correct: Statement A is incorrect. Beryllium does form compounds with oxygen — notably BeO (beryllium oxide), which is a very high melting point refractory material. BeO is amphoteric (dissolving in both acids and alkalis). What makes Be anomalous is the covalent nature and amphoteric character of its oxide, not the absence of oxygen compounds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Statements B, C, and D are all correct. Be has only 2s and 2p orbitals (no 2d), so its maximum coordination number is 4 (as in [BeF₄]²⁻). BeCl₂ is covalent (Fajans' rules) while CaCl₂ is ionic. Be does show diagonal relationship with Al. Only statement A (no oxygen compounds) is factually wrong.

questions.question_text: Lithium shows several anomalous properties within Group 1. Which of the following is an anomalous property of lithium?

options.text: Li forms a stable bicarbonate (LiHCO₃) in solid state
LiCl is deliquescent and soluble in organic solvents due to covalent character
Li₂CO₃ is highly soluble in water like Na₂CO₃
Li forms superoxide (LiO₂) when burned in excess O₂

questions.explanation_correct: LiCl is deliquescent (absorbs moisture from air) and is soluble in organic solvents like ethanol and acetone due to its significant covalent character. The small Li⁺ ion strongly polarises the large Cl⁻ (Fajans' rules), imparting covalent character. This is unlike NaCl, KCl, etc., which are typically insoluble in organic solvents. This is one of lithium's anomalous properties showing its resemblance to Mg (diagonal relationship).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Li does not form stable solid LiHCO₃ (LiHCO₃ exists only in solution, unlike NaHCO₃ which is a stable solid). Li₂CO₃ is sparingly soluble (unlike Na₂CO₃ which is very soluble). Li forms only Li₂O (normal oxide), not superoxide or peroxide.

questions.question_text: Dead burnt plaster is formed when gypsum (CaSO₄·2H₂O) is heated above 473 K. It cannot be used as plaster because:

options.text: It becomes Ca(OH)₂ which is soluble
It becomes anhydrous CaSO₄ which does not set with water
It decomposes to CaO and SO₃
It converts to CaCO₃ which is insoluble

questions.explanation_correct: When gypsum is heated above 473 K, it loses all water of crystallisation to form anhydrous CaSO₄ (dead burnt plaster): CaSO₄·2H₂O →(>473 K) CaSO₄ + 2H₂O. Unlike the hemihydrate (Plaster of Paris), anhydrous CaSO₄ has undergone structural reorganisation and cannot readily re-absorb water to form gypsum. Therefore, it does not set with water and is useless as plaster.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dead burnt plaster does not become Ca(OH)₂, CaO + SO₃, or CaCO₃. It is simply anhydrous CaSO₄ that has lost the ability to rehydrate and set. The crystal structure of the anhydrous form is too stable and compact to incorporate water molecules back into its lattice.

questions.question_text: Which of the following compounds of calcium is used for disinfecting drinking water?
questions.explanation_correct: Bleaching powder [Ca(OCl)Cl or CaOCl₂, calcium hypochlorite mixed with calcium chloride] is used for disinfecting drinking water. It is prepared by passing chlorine gas over slaked lime: 2Ca(OH)₂ + 2Cl₂ → Ca(OCl)₂ + CaCl₂ + 2H₂O (simplified as Ca(OH)₂ + Cl₂ → Ca(OCl)Cl + H₂O). The OCl⁻ (hypochlorite) ion acts as a strong oxidising agent that kills bacteria and other pathogens in water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CaCO₃ (limestone) is used in construction and as a flux, not for water disinfection. Gypsum is used in plaster and cement. Ca₃(PO₄)₂ is present in bones and used in fertilisers. Only bleaching powder, with its active chlorine content, serves as a water disinfectant.
